‎01-08-2012 08:27 AM

Is there anything that won't mess with blood sugar? I need something to get back on track.

I usually wake up early in the morning and have a rough time getting back to sleep.

 

First test A1c 6.8
A1C 5.7 (2 month home test)
3 month A1c 5.4
6/22/12 A1c 5.4 (home test)
11/8/12 A1C 6.0
4/18/2013 A1C 5.4
12/22/13 A1c 6.3 (home test)

Diet and exercise

‎01-08-2012 10:24 AM

RedKat wrote:

Is there anything that won't mess with blood sugar? I need something to get back on track.

I usually wake up early in the morning and have a rough time getting back to sleep.

 

I've not heard of any that raise your BG numbers, I take half a Unisom tab every night and have been doing so for several years.  My doctor said that's okay to do.  Here's something I wrote about it:

 

Get Some Sleep Folks

‎01-08-2012 10:49 AM

RedKat:  I have used (from Costco) "Sleep Aid."  When I wake up in the middle of the night and can't get back to sleep, I use 1/2 of one and never had a problem with blood sugar.  I have also tried Melatonin but it doresn't work as well as "Sleep Aid" for getting back to sleep.

My mom uses generic Benadryl.  It is the same active ingredient as many of the OTC sleep aids.

Re: OTC Sleep aids

‎01-08-2012 01:53 PM

Anything containing Diphenhydramine HCL as the active ingredient should be fine.  This is found commonly in most sleep aids, and in antihystamines such as Benadryl.

 

However, some use Doxicycline Succonate.  While this is also acceptable, it may affect DP (if you have DP) slightly. 

 

Hope that helps!

~Rae~ (Type 1.5, aka LADA)

 Treat every stressful situation like a dog... if you can't eat it or play with it, just pee on it and walk away...

Advair, Albuterol-Isopro mix, Bystolic, Colchicine, Combivent, Fentanyl,   Fish Oil, Furosemide,  Humulin R U-500, Hydroxazine, Iron, Klor-Con, Lipitor, L-Lysine, Magnesium,  Metolazone, Oxycodone, Spironolactone, Topamax, Trilipix, Uloric, Vitamin D 50,000,  Zoloft. 

(Hey, if you took all these meds, you'd need happy pills too!)

Re: OTC Sleep aids

‎01-08-2012 02:47 PM

My response is going to be different than the rest, I would avoid any OTC sleep aids as much as possible and talk to your doctor about your sleep issues and get a referral to a sleep specialist and do a sleep study first. Sleep problems are usually a symptom of some underling issues, either physiological or psychological, and in many cases can be resolved without the use of sleep aids. I also had a very difficult time with getting a good nights sleep for many years, the first issue I resolved was getting Dx as a Type-II, the frequent trips to the bathroom during the night, as many a 5-6 times a night, was resolved when I got my BG under control. Then there was the snoring that my wife complained about so my doctor referred me for a sleep study and I was Dx with sleep apnea and put on CPAP treatment and that issue was resolved. The final issue was insomnia and I have now taken steps to resolve that issue without sleep aids. Now I sleep very well, a solid 7-8 hours a night, no middle of the night wake-ups and daytime drowsiness is a thing of the past. The insomnia was the toughest issue to resolve, but with patience and foliowing through with the recommend lifestyle changes I was able to take care of it without sleep aids too.

‎01-08-2012 03:46 PM

RedKat wrote:

Thanks for all the answers and links. Good to know I can take that stuff in a pinch. 

I agree it's probably best to do it naturally, but sometimes I just need to get some sleep.

 

I think my mind is the main culprit once I wake up....thinking about not sleeping is stressful

 

 

One of the methods I use to calm my mind down to relax into deep restful sleep is mediation by using brainwave entrainment with binaural beats and isochronic tones. Meditation naturally is very difficult to achieve without years of practice but with the wonders of modern technology I have found that the same effects can be achieved by listening to audio recordings for relaxation.
